canonical_explanation.text: In physics, work is done when a force causes displacement of an object. Work = Force × Displacement (in the direction of force). The SI unit of work is Joule (J). Work is positive when force and displacement are in the same direction, negative when opposite, and zero when perpendicular. Energy is the capacity to do work. It exists in various forms including mechanical (kinetic and potential), heat, light, sound, electrical, chemical, and nuclear. Kinetic energy is energy due to motion (KE = ½mv²). Potential energy is energy due to position (PE = mgh for gravitational). The law of conservation of energy states that energy can neither be created nor destroyed, only transformed.
rules: SI unit of work is Joule (J) = Newton-meter
Work is done only when displacement occurs in the direction of force.
Energy is the capacity to do work.
Gravitational Potential Energy = mgh (energy of position)
Law of conservation of energy: Energy cannot be created or destroyed.
Energy can only be transformed from one form to another.
Total mechanical energy = Kinetic energy + Potential energy

questions.question_text: When is work said to be done?
questions.explanation_correct: Work is said to be done when a force causes an object to move in the direction of the force. This is because work is the product of force and the displacement of the object in the direction of the force.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because simply applying a force does not mean work is done. Option C is incorrect because the weight of an object does not determine whether work is done. Option D is incorrect because storing energy is not the same as doing work. The correct answer is option B, as work is only done when the force causes the object to move or be displaced.

questions.question_text: What is the SI unit of work?
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of work is Joule (J) because work is defined as the product of force and displacement in the direction of the force. The formula for work is W = F × d, where W is work, F is force, and d is displacement. The SI unit for force is Newton (N) and the SI unit for displacement is meter (m), so the SI unit for work is Newton-meter (N⋅m), which is also known as the Joule (J).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not the correct SI unit of work. Newton (N) is the SI unit of force, Watt (W) is the SI unit of power, and Pascal (Pa) is the SI unit of pressure. While these are all important units in physics, they are not the unit used to measure work, which is the Joule (J).

questions.question_text: Energy is defined as:

options.text: The force applied on an object

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) The capacity to do work. Energy is defined as the ability or capacity to do work, which means to apply a force and cause an object to move in the direction of the force. Energy is not a force itself, but rather the potential to exert a force and perform work.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers are not correct because they do not accurately define energy. A) The force applied on an object is not the definition of energy, as force and energy are different physical concepts. C) The mass of an object is also not the definition of energy. D) The speed of an object is a measure of kinetic energy, which is one form of energy, but speed itself is not the definition of energy.

questions.question_text: The energy possessed by a moving object is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The energy possessed by a moving object is called kinetic energy. This is because kinetic energy is the energy of motion, and a moving object has kinetic energy due to its motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Potential energy is the energy an object has due to its position or height, like a ball held above the ground. Chemical energy is the energy stored in the bonds of chemical compounds, like the energy in food. Heat energy is the thermal energy of an object, like the warmth of a hot object. None of these types of energy describe the energy a moving object possesses, which is kinetic energy.

questions.question_text: The energy possessed by an object due to its position or height is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The energy possessed by an object due to its position or height is called potential energy. This is because the object has the potential to do work due to its position or height, for example, a ball held at a certain height above the ground has potential energy which can be converted into kinetic energy as it falls.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Kinetic energy is the energy possessed by an object due to its motion, not its position. Nuclear energy and sound energy are different forms of energy that are not related to the position or height of an object. Potential energy is the correct answer as it describes the energy an object has due to its position or height.

questions.question_text: A porter carries a bag on his head and stands still. The work done by him is:
questions.explanation_correct: The work done by the porter is zero because the force applied by him (the weight of the bag) does not cause any displacement of the bag. The bag remains stationary, so the displacement is zero. According to the formula, work = force × displacement, and since the displacement is zero, the work done is also zero.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The work done by the porter is not positive or negative because the bag is not moving. For work to be positive, the force and displacement must be in the same direction. For work to be negative, the force and displacement must be in opposite directions. Since the bag is stationary, there is no displacement, and therefore the work done is zero.

questions.question_text: If a force of 50 N moves an object by 4 m in the direction of force, the work done is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 200 J. The formula for work done is Force × Displacement. With a force of 50 N and a displacement of 4 m in the same direction, the work done is 50 N × 4 m = 200 J.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers are not correct because they do not match the work done calculation. Work is calculated by multiplying the force and the displacement in the same direction. A force of 50 N moving an object by 4 m in the same direction results in a work done of 200 J.

questions.question_text: When a ball is thrown upwards, at its maximum height:
questions.explanation_correct: At the maximum height, the ball has no kinetic energy because it is momentarily at rest. However, it has maximum potential energy due to its position high up in the air, against the force of gravity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When a ball is thrown upwards, its kinetic energy decreases as it slows down, and its potential energy increases as it rises higher. At the maximum height, the ball has no kinetic energy, but its potential energy is at the maximum.

questions.question_text: According to the law of conservation of energy:
questions.explanation_correct: The law of conservation of energy states that energy can only be transformed from one form to another, and cannot be created or destroyed. This means that the total amount of energy in the universe remains constant, it just changes its form.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The law of conservation of energy does not allow for energy to be created or destroyed. Option A and B are incorrect because energy cannot be created or destroyed. Option D is incorrect because energy does not increase over time, it just changes form. The correct option is C, which states that energy can only be transformed.

questions.question_text: If the velocity of an object is doubled, its kinetic energy becomes:
questions.explanation_correct: If the velocity of an object is doubled, its kinetic energy becomes four times. This is because kinetic energy is proportional to the square of the velocity (KE = 1/2mv^2), and when the velocity is doubled, the squared term becomes 4 times the original value.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not accurately reflect how kinetic energy changes when velocity changes. Kinetic energy is not simply double or half the original value when velocity doubles, it becomes four times the original value. This is because kinetic energy is proportional to the square of the velocity, so doubling the velocity results in the kinetic energy becoming four times larger.

questions.question_text: Work is done even when there is no displacement.
questions.explanation_correct: Work is only done when there is a force acting on an object and the object is displaced in the direction of the force. If there is no displacement, even if a force is applied, no work is done.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement 'Work is done even when there is no displacement' is incorrect. For work to be done, there must be a displacement of the object in the direction of the applied force. If an object is not displaced, even if a force is acting on it, no work is done. Work is defined as the product of force and displacement in the direction of the force.

questions.question_text: A flying bird has both kinetic and potential energy.
questions.explanation_correct: A flying bird has both kinetic energy due to its motion and potential energy due to its position in the Earth's gravitational field. This is because the bird is moving (kinetic energy) and is also higher up in the air (potential energy).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be to say that a flying bird only has kinetic energy. This is not correct because the bird is also experiencing a force of gravity, which gives it potential energy due to its position above the ground. Both kinetic and potential energy are present in a flying bird.

questions.question_text: When a pendulum swings, energy is continuously transformed between kinetic and potential forms.
questions.explanation_correct: When a pendulum swings, its energy is continuously transformed between kinetic energy (when it is moving) and potential energy (when it is at the highest point of its swing). This is because the pendulum's energy changes from kinetic to potential and back again as it moves up and down.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true because the energy of a swinging pendulum is continuously transformed between kinetic and potential forms. At the highest point of its swing, the pendulum has maximum potential energy, while at the bottom of its swing, it has maximum kinetic energy. This energy transformation occurs throughout the pendulum's motion.

questions.question_text: The work done by gravity on a satellite moving in a circular orbit is zero.
questions.explanation_correct: The work done by gravity on a satellite moving in a circular orbit is not zero. Even though the satellite's direction of motion is perpendicular to the gravitational force, the satellite is continuously accelerating towards the center of the circular path, and this acceleration requires a centripetal force that is provided by gravity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement 'The work done by gravity on a satellite moving in a circular orbit is zero' is incorrect. This is because the satellite is continuously accelerating towards the center of the circular path, and this acceleration requires a centripetal force that is provided by gravity. Since the force of gravity is not perpendicular to the direction of motion, the work done by gravity is not zero.

questions.question_text: Work equals force multiplied by ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Work is defined as the product of force and the displacement of an object in the direction of the force. This means that the amount of work done is directly proportional to the distance the object moves in the direction of the applied force.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be 'time'. Work is not equal to force multiplied by time. Work is the energy transferred to an object by a force acting on it over a distance. The correct formula for work is work = force × displacement, where displacement refers to the distance the object moves in the direction of the applied force.

questions.question_text: Kinetic energy is the energy of ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Kinetic energy is the energy of motion because an object in motion has energy due to its movement. When an object is moving, it has the ability to do work and cause changes, which is what kinetic energy represents.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'motion'. Kinetic energy is not the energy of position or potential energy, which is the energy stored due to an object's position or height. Kinetic energy is specifically the energy an object has because it is in motion and moving.

questions.question_text: The formula for gravitational potential energy is PE = m × g × ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The formula for gravitational potential energy is PE = m × g × h, where h represents the height or vertical displacement of the object. This is because the potential energy of an object is directly proportional to its mass, the acceleration due to gravity, and the height it is raised above the ground.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer format is 'h', as the formula for gravitational potential energy is PE = m × g × h. This means that the potential energy depends on the mass of the object, the acceleration due to gravity, and the height of the object above the ground. The other variables, such as velocity or force, are not part of the formula for gravitational potential energy.

questions.question_text: According to the law of ___ of energy, energy cannot be created or destroyed.
questions.explanation_correct: The law of conservation of energy states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, it can only be transformed from one form to another. This means that the total amount of energy in the universe remains constant, it just changes shape or type.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'conservation'. This is because the law of conservation of energy states that energy cannot be created or destroyed. It can only change from one form to another, such as from kinetic energy to potential energy. So the word that best fills the blank is 'conservation' to describe this fundamental law of physics.

questions.question_text: Arrange the energy forms as a ball falls from a height:
ordering_items: Equal PE and KE at midpoint
correct_answer: Equal PE and KE at midpoint
questions.explanation_correct: As a ball falls from a height, its potential energy is maximum at the top, then decreases as it falls. At the midpoint, the potential energy and kinetic energy are equal. By the time it reaches the ground, the ball has maximum kinetic energy and no potential energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect arrangement would be: Equal PE and KE at the top, Maximum KE at midpoint, Maximum PE at ground. This is incorrect because the ball has the most potential energy at the top, not the equal amounts of potential and kinetic energy. Also, the kinetic energy is maximum at the ground, not the midpoint, as the ball has accelerated downwards due to gravity.

questions.question_text: Arrange these forms of energy that occur when you switch on a light bulb:
questions.explanation_correct: When you switch on a light bulb, electrical energy is first converted into heat energy, which then causes the filament in the bulb to emit light energy. This sequence of energy transformations is the correct order of the forms of energy that occur in a light bulb.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If you were to arrange the forms of energy in the wrong order, such as Light energy, Electrical energy, Heat energy, it would be incorrect. This is because the electrical energy in the circuit first gets converted into heat energy in the filament, which then causes the filament to glow and emit light energy. The correct order is Electrical energy, Heat energy, Light energy.

questions.question_text: 1 Joule equals:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is D, both A and C. 1 Joule is equal to 1 Newton-meter, which is the SI unit of work, and 1 Watt-second, which is another way to express the unit of work (1 Watt = 1 Joule/second).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is correct because 1 Joule is equal to 1 Newton-meter, which is the SI unit of work. Work is calculated as force multiplied by displacement, and the unit for this is Newton-meter, which is the same as Joule. Option B is incorrect because 1 Newton/meter is the unit of force per unit length, not work. Option C is also correct because 1 Joule is equal to 1 Watt-second, which is another way to express the unit of work.

questions.question_text: Work is a:
questions.explanation_correct: Work is a scalar quantity because it only has a magnitude (numerical value) and no direction associated with it. The work done on an object is the product of the force applied and the displacement in the direction of the force, which is a scalar quantity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Work is not a vector quantity because it does not have a direction associated with it. A vector quantity has both magnitude and direction, like displacement, velocity, or force. Work is the product of a force and the displacement in the direction of the force, so it is a scalar quantity.

questions.question_text: The formula for kinetic energy is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct formula for kinetic energy (KE) is KE = ½mv², where m is the mass of the object and v is its velocity. This formula captures the fact that kinetic energy is directly proportional to the square of the velocity, which aligns with our understanding that faster-moving objects have more kinetic energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options do not correctly represent the formula for kinetic energy. Option A, KE = mv, is incorrect as it does not include the factor of ½. Option C, KE = mgh, is the formula for gravitational potential energy, not kinetic energy. Option D, KE = mv², is incorrect as it does not include the factor of ½.

questions.question_text: Which form of energy is stored in food?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) Chemical energy. Food contains stored chemical energy in the form of chemical bonds between atoms and molecules. This chemical energy can be released and converted to other forms of energy, like heat and mechanical energy, when the food is broken down and used by the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not correct. Kinetic energy is the energy of motion, heat energy is thermal energy, and light energy is the energy of electromagnetic radiation. Food does not primarily store these forms of energy. The energy in food is stored in the chemical bonds of its molecules, which can be released and used by the body.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of energy is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) Joule. This is because the SI unit of energy is Joule (J), which measures the amount of work done or energy transferred. Work and energy are related concepts, and Joule is the standard unit used to quantify both.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not the correct SI unit of energy. A) Newton is the unit of force, B) Watt is the unit of power, and D) Pascal is the unit of pressure. Energy is a different physical quantity, and Joule is the appropriate unit to measure it.

questions.question_text: Work done is positive when:

options.text: Force and displacement are in the same direction

questions.explanation_correct: When the force and displacement are in the same direction, work done is positive. This is because the force is doing work to move the object in the same direction as the force is applied.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Work is positive when the force and displacement are in the same direction. This means the force is helping to move the object in the same way it is applied. If the force and displacement are perpendicular, the work done is zero. If they are opposite, the work done is negative, meaning the force is opposing the motion.

questions.question_text: A 2 kg object is moving with velocity 3 m/s. Its kinetic energy is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 9 J. The kinetic energy of an object is given by the formula KE = 1/2 × m × v^2, where m is the mass and v is the velocity. Plugging in the given values, we get KE = 1/2 × 2 kg × (3 m/s)^2 = 9 J.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are: A) 6 J, C) 18 J, and D) 3 J. The correct formula to calculate the kinetic energy is KE = 1/2 × m × v^2, where m is the mass and v is the velocity. Plugging in the given values of m = 2 kg and v = 3 m/s, the correct kinetic energy is 9 J.

questions.question_text: A 5 kg object is lifted to a height of 4 m. The potential energy gained is: (g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) 200 J. This is because the potential energy gained by the object is given by the formula PE = mgh, where m is the mass of the object (5 kg), g is the acceleration due to gravity (10 m/s²), and h is the height the object is lifted (4 m). Plugging in the values, we get PE = 5 kg × 10 m/s² × 4 m = 200 J.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not correctly apply the formula for potential energy. Option A) 50 J is too low, option B) 100 J is half the correct value, and option D) 20 J is too low. The correct answer is 200 J, as calculated using the formula PE = mgh.

questions.question_text: A person pushes a wall but the wall does not move. The work done is:
questions.explanation_correct: The work done is zero because the wall does not move even though a force is applied. Since work is defined as the product of force and displacement in the direction of the force, if there is no displacement, the work done is zero.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The work done is not positive or negative because the wall does not move. Work can only be positive if the force and displacement are in the same direction, and negative if they are in opposite directions. Since there is no displacement here, the work done is zero.

questions.question_text: In a hydroelectric power plant, which energy conversion takes place?
questions.explanation_correct: In a hydroelectric power plant, the energy conversion that takes place is from potential energy to kinetic energy to electrical energy. The water stored in the dam has potential energy due to its height. As the water flows downward, this potential energy is converted to kinetic energy. The moving water then spins the turbines, which in turn generate electrical energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because they do not accurately describe the energy conversion in a hydroelectric power plant. Option A, 'Chemical to electrical', is wrong as there is no chemical energy involved in a hydroelectric plant. Option C, 'Nuclear to electrical', is incorrect as hydroelectric power plants do not use nuclear energy. Option D, 'Solar to electrical', is also wrong as the energy source in a hydroelectric plant is not solar energy.

questions.question_text: Work done against friction is always:
questions.explanation_correct: The work done against friction is always positive because the force of friction opposes the motion of the object, and the object has to do work to overcome this force. This means that the force and the displacement are in opposite directions, resulting in positive work being done.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The work done against friction is not negative or zero. Negative work would mean the object is gaining energy from the friction, which is not the case. Zero work would mean the object is not moving at all, which is also not true when there is friction present. The correct answer is that the work done against friction is always positive, as the object has to do work to overcome the opposing force of friction.

questions.question_text: A stretched rubber band has:
questions.explanation_correct: A stretched rubber band has elastic potential energy. This is because the rubber band has been stretched and has the ability to do work by returning to its original shape, which stores energy in the elastic material.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because a stretched rubber band does not have kinetic energy (it is not moving), gravitational potential energy (it is not lifted against gravity), or no energy (it clearly has the ability to do work).

questions.question_text: If mass is doubled and velocity is halved, the kinetic energy:
questions.explanation_correct: The kinetic energy of an object is given by the formula KE = 1/2 * m * v^2. If the mass is doubled, the kinetic energy will double. But if the velocity is halved, the kinetic energy will be reduced by a factor of 4 (1/2 * 1/2 = 1/4). Therefore, the overall kinetic energy will be halved.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the mass is doubled and the velocity is halved, the kinetic energy will not remain the same. The correct answer is that the kinetic energy will be halved. This is because the kinetic energy formula KE = 1/2 * m * v^2 shows that if the mass is doubled (m becomes 2m), the kinetic energy will double. But if the velocity is halved (v becomes v/2), the kinetic energy will be reduced by a factor of 4 (1/2 * (v/2)^2 = 1/4 * 1/2 * v^2 = 1/8 * m * v^2). The overall effect is that the kinetic energy will be halved.

questions.question_text: A ball is dropped from height h. At height h/2, the ratio of PE to KE is:
questions.explanation_correct: At height h/2, the ball has lost half its original potential energy (PE = mgh), but its kinetic energy (KE = 1/2mv^2) has only increased by a factor of 2 since its velocity has increased by a factor of √2. Therefore, the ratio of PE to KE at height h/2 is 1:1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B (2:1) is incorrect because the ball has lost half its original potential energy at height h/2, but its kinetic energy has increased by a factor of 2. Option C (1:2) is incorrect because the ball's kinetic energy has only increased by a factor of 2, not a factor of 4. Option D (3:1) is incorrect because the ball has lost half its original potential energy, not two-thirds of it.

questions.question_text: Work done by gravity on a body moving horizontally is:
questions.explanation_correct: The work done by gravity on a body moving horizontally is zero. This is because the force of gravity (weight) acts vertically downward, while the displacement of the body is horizontal. Since the force and displacement are perpendicular to each other, the work done is zero.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The work done by gravity is not positive or negative, as the force of gravity is perpendicular to the horizontal motion of the body. The work done is zero because the force and displacement are in different directions. It is not the maximum work either, as the maximum work would occur if the force and displacement were in the same direction.

questions.question_text: Two bodies have equal kinetic energy. Body A is twice as heavy as body B. The ratio of their velocities (A:B) is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A (1:√2). Since the two bodies have equal kinetic energy, their kinetic energies are the same (KE = 1/2mv^2). Since body A is twice as heavy as body B, the velocity of body A must be √2 times smaller than the velocity of body B to maintain the same kinetic energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers are not correct. B (√2:1) is wrong because if body A is twice as heavy as body B, then the velocity of A should be √2 times smaller than the velocity of B to maintain the same kinetic energy. C (1:2) is wrong because the ratio of the velocities should be the inverse of the square root of the mass ratio, not the direct mass ratio. D (2:1) is wrong because if body A is twice as heavy as body B, the velocity of A should be √2 times smaller than the velocity of B, not twice as large.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a form of energy?
questions.explanation_correct: Force is not a form of energy. Energy refers to the ability to do work, while force is the push or pull that causes an object to move. The other options (heat, light, and sound) are all different forms of energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Force is a physical quantity that describes the interaction between objects, not a form of energy. Energy is the capacity to do work and can take many forms, such as heat, light, sound, electrical, and so on. The correct forms of energy listed in the options are heat, light, and sound.

questions.question_text: Work done is negative when:

options.text: Force and displacement are in the same direction

questions.explanation_correct: The work done is negative when the force and displacement are in opposite directions. This is because the force is acting against the direction of motion, and the work done will be negative.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Work is negative when the force and displacement are in opposite directions. If the force and displacement are in the same direction, the work done will be positive. If the force is zero, no work is done. And if the displacement is zero, no work is done either. Therefore, option B is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: In a torch, which energy conversion takes place?
questions.explanation_correct: In a torch, the energy conversion that takes place is from chemical energy to electrical energy, and then to light energy. The battery in the torch contains chemical energy, which is converted to electrical energy that powers the bulb, and finally this electrical energy is converted to light energy that illuminates the surroundings.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not correct because: A) Electrical to chemical energy conversion does not take place in a torch, as the battery already contains chemical energy. C) Light to electrical energy conversion is not the process in a torch, as the bulb converts electrical energy to light energy. D) Heat to light energy conversion is not the process in a torch, as the bulb converts electrical energy to light energy, not heat to light.

questions.question_text: A stationary object at rest has:
questions.explanation_correct: A stationary object at rest has only potential energy, not kinetic energy. This is because potential energy is the energy an object has due to its position or height, while kinetic energy is the energy an object has due to its motion. Since a stationary object is not moving, it has no kinetic energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer is that a stationary object at rest has both kinetic and potential energy. This is not correct because a stationary object is not in motion, so it does not have any kinetic energy. The object may have potential energy if it is elevated, but it does not have both types of energy at the same time when it is at rest.

questions.question_text: Work and energy have the same SI unit.
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of work is Joule (J), and the SI unit of energy is also Joule (J). Since work and energy are related concepts, they share the same unit of measurement, which is Joule (J).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Work and energy are related but not exactly the same. Work is the product of force and displacement, while energy is the capacity to do work. Even though they are measured in the same unit of Joule (J), they represent different physical quantities. Work is a scalar quantity, while energy can be in different forms, such as kinetic, potential, thermal, and others.

questions.question_text: Kinetic energy can never be negative.
questions.explanation_correct: Kinetic energy can never be negative because it is the energy an object has due to its motion. Since an object's speed cannot be negative, the formula for kinetic energy (KE = 1/2 mv^2) will always give a positive value.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Kinetic energy can be negative in certain situations. For example, if an object is slowing down or moving in the opposite direction of the force acting on it, the work done on the object would be negative. However, this does not mean the kinetic energy itself is negative. Kinetic energy is always a positive quantity, as it represents the energy an object has due to its motion.

questions.question_text: In a frictionless system, mechanical energy is always conserved.
questions.explanation_correct: In a frictionless system, mechanical energy (the sum of kinetic and potential energy) is always conserved. This means that the total mechanical energy of the system remains constant and is not lost to other forms of energy like heat or sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Some students may think that mechanical energy is not always conserved, even in a frictionless system. This is not correct. In the absence of friction or other non-conservative forces, the total mechanical energy of the system remains constant and is simply converted between kinetic and potential energy as the object moves.

questions.question_text: Doubling the height doubles the potential energy.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, this statement is true. The potential energy of an object is directly proportional to its height. If the height is doubled, the potential energy will also double, since the formula for potential energy is PE = mgh, and 'h' (height) is multiplied.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is incorrect. Potential energy is not directly proportional to height in a linear way. The formula for potential energy is PE = mgh, where 'm' is the mass of the object and 'g' is the acceleration due to gravity. Doubling the height will result in the potential energy doubling, not just the height.

questions.question_text: Work done by a force perpendicular to displacement is zero.
questions.explanation_correct: The statement is true. When a force is perpendicular to the displacement of an object, the work done by that force is zero. This is because the work done is the product of the force and the displacement in the direction of the force, and if the force and displacement are perpendicular, the displacement in the direction of the force is zero.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is incorrect. If a force is perpendicular to the displacement of an object, the work done by that force is not zero. This is because the work done is the product of the force and the displacement in the direction of the force. Even though the force and displacement are perpendicular, the displacement in the direction of the force is not zero, so the work done is also not zero.

questions.question_text: At any point during free fall, total mechanical energy remains constant (ignoring air resistance).
questions.explanation_correct: During free fall, the total mechanical energy (kinetic energy + potential energy) of an object remains constant, ignoring air resistance. This is because the object's loss in potential energy is exactly balanced by the gain in its kinetic energy as it falls.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is a common misconception that the total mechanical energy does not remain constant during free fall. However, this is incorrect. As an object falls, its potential energy decreases, but this energy is converted into kinetic energy. The total sum of these two forms of mechanical energy remains the same throughout the free fall, unless there are external factors like air resistance that affect the energy.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of work is the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of work is the Joule (J) because work is defined as the product of force and displacement in the direction of the force. The Joule is the standard unit for measuring this quantity in the International System of Units.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is Joule (J). This is because work is a measure of the energy transferred by a force acting on an object as it moves in the direction of the force. The SI unit for work is therefore the Joule, which is the unit for energy. Other units like Newton-meter or kilogram-meter per second squared are not the correct SI unit for work.

questions.question_text: The formula for kinetic energy is KE = ½m___.
questions.explanation_correct: The formula for kinetic energy is KE = ½mv², where m is the mass of the object and v is its velocity. This formula is correct because kinetic energy depends on the square of the velocity, so the missing term in the question must be v².
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be to fill in the blank with 'mass' or 'm'. This is not correct because the formula for kinetic energy is KE = ½mv², where m is the mass and v is the velocity. The missing term in the question must be the velocity squared, v², not the mass.

questions.question_text: ___ energy is the capacity to do work.
questions.explanation_correct: The answer 'Energy' is correct because energy is defined as the capacity to do work. Work is the product of force and displacement, so energy is what enables an object to do work and move through space.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'Energy'. The incorrect answer would be something like 'Kinetic' or 'Potential', which are specific types of energy. However, the overall concept of 'energy' is the broader term that refers to the capacity to do work, which is what the question is asking about.

questions.question_text: Energy stored due to an object's height is called ___ potential energy.
questions.explanation_correct: The energy stored due to an object's height is called gravitational potential energy. This is because the object has potential energy due to its position in the Earth's gravitational field, which is determined by its height or altitude.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'gravitational' potential energy. Potential energy is the energy an object has due to its position or configuration. When an object is raised to a certain height, it gains gravitational potential energy, which is the energy it has due to its position in the Earth's gravitational field. This is different from other forms of potential energy, such as elastic potential energy or electrical potential energy.

questions.question_text: Work = Force × ___ (in the direction of force).
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is 'displacement' because the formula for work is Work = Force × Displacement, where 'displacement' refers to the distance an object moves in the direction of the applied force.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'displacement'. The formula for work is Work = Force × Displacement, not Force × Time or Force × Acceleration. Work is done when a force causes an object to move in the direction of the force, so the missing term in the formula is the displacement of the object.

questions.question_text: Energy can be ___ from one form to another but cannot be created or destroyed.
questions.explanation_correct: The law of conservation of energy states that energy can only be transformed from one form to another, but cannot be created or destroyed. This means that the total amount of energy in a closed system remains constant, even as it changes forms. The correct answer is 'transformed'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be 'created' or 'destroyed'. Energy cannot be created or destroyed, as this would violate the law of conservation of energy. Instead, energy can only be transformed from one form to another, such as from kinetic energy to potential energy or vice versa. The correct answer is 'transformed', which accurately describes how energy changes form but not its total amount.

questions.question_text: Total mechanical energy equals kinetic energy plus ___ energy.
questions.explanation_correct: The total mechanical energy of an object is the sum of its kinetic energy and potential energy. Kinetic energy is the energy of motion, while potential energy is the energy an object has due to its position or configuration. Therefore, the total mechanical energy equals the kinetic energy plus the potential energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'potential'. The total mechanical energy of an object is not just its kinetic energy, but the sum of its kinetic energy and potential energy. Potential energy is the energy an object has due to its position or configuration, such as the gravitational potential energy of an object raised above the ground. Therefore, the total mechanical energy equals the kinetic energy plus the potential energy.

questions.question_text: The energy stored in a compressed spring is called ___ potential energy.
questions.explanation_correct: The energy stored in a compressed spring is called elastic potential energy. This is because the spring is able to store energy due to its ability to be compressed or stretched, which is a form of elastic potential energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The energy stored in a compressed spring is not called gravitational potential energy. Gravitational potential energy is the energy an object has due to its position in a gravitational field, such as being lifted up from the ground. In the case of a compressed spring, the energy is stored due to the spring's ability to be compressed, which is a form of elastic potential energy.

questions.question_text: Arrange energy conversions when you rub your hands together:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is Muscular energy used, Friction acts, Heat energy produced. This is because when you rub your hands together, your muscles provide the energy to create the friction, which in turn produces heat energy due to the rubbing motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be Heat energy produced, Friction acts, Muscular energy used. This is wrong because the muscular energy is used first to create the rubbing motion, which then causes friction, and finally the friction produces the heat energy. The correct order is Muscular energy used, Friction acts, and then Heat energy produced.

questions.question_text: Arrange objects by increasing kinetic energy (same mass, different speeds):
questions.explanation_correct: The kinetic energy of an object is directly proportional to its speed squared. So an object moving at 10 m/s has higher kinetic energy than an object moving at 5 m/s, and an object at rest has no kinetic energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An object at rest has no kinetic energy, since it is not moving. An object moving at 5 m/s has less kinetic energy than an object moving at 10 m/s, because kinetic energy depends on the square of the speed. Therefore, the correct order from lowest to highest kinetic energy is: At rest, Moving at 5 m/s, Moving at 10 m/s.

questions.question_text: For a ball thrown upward, arrange the KE values:
questions.explanation_correct: The kinetic energy of the ball is zero at the maximum height, as the ball is momentarily at rest. At half the maximum height, the ball has some kinetic energy, as it is still moving upwards. Just after throwing, the ball has the highest kinetic energy as it is moving the fastest.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: Just after throwing, At half the maximum height, At maximum height. This is incorrect because at the maximum height, the ball is momentarily at rest and has no kinetic energy. As the ball moves upwards, its kinetic energy decreases until it reaches the maximum height, where it is zero. On the way down, the kinetic energy increases again.

questions.question_text: Arrange energy transformations in a solar cell:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is: Light energy absorbed, Electron movement in cell, Electrical energy output. This is because in a solar cell, the absorbed light energy causes the electrons in the cell to start moving, which then generates an electrical current that can be used as electrical energy output.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: Electron movement in cell, Electrical energy output, Light energy absorbed. This is wrong because the light energy must first be absorbed by the solar cell before it can cause the electrons to move, which then leads to the generation of electrical energy output. The correct order starts with the absorption of light energy, which then triggers the electron movement and finally results in the electrical energy output.
